--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Kent Beck" <kentb@...> wrote:
>
> Ben,
> 
> =
Thank you for the feedback. We went around on this. It seems there
are two
=
> cases:
> 
> 1) I am throwing an exception but I want to make it more spec=
ific so
I throw
> a subclass (Exception -> IllegalArgumentException). No ca=
tch clauses
care
> about the more-specific exception. If expected is lookin=
g for a precise
> class, a bunch of tests will break even though the code s=
till works.

I've never seen an api that says "when you do X, we will throw=
 a
random type of exception (though it will derive from Y)"

And if this is=
 a common case, what about the case "We can throw either
an IllegalArgument=
Exception or a FileNotFoundException but nothing
else". I think cases like =
#1 will still need to be done with the
manual patern (this is what NUnit pi=
oneered with their expected
exception stuff, so I'd tend to agree with thei=
r choice).
 
> Either way you're going to get false results. One question i=
s which
scenario
> is more common? Another is which scenario is more
danger=
ous/risky/expensive?

I'd argue that case 2 is much more common.

-- Ben
